Front: What are the EXACT steps to configure auto-swap for Azure App Service deployment slots to ensure zero-downtime deployments?
Back:
1. Create deployment slot (staging)
2. Configure during slot creation OR in deployment settings
3. Enable Auto-Swap to automatically swap staging to production after deployment completion
4. System performs automatic warm-up process before swap
5. Fail-safe rollback if deployment health checks fail
6. Perfect integration with CI/CD pipelines

**Key Benefit:** Zero-downtime deployment with automatic warm-up and health validation

Front: You need to securely connect an App Service to Azure SQL Database. What is the CORRECT sequence to avoid connectivity loss? (Choose the sequence: A-Service Endpoint, B-Disable Public Access, C-VNet Integration, D-Firewall Rules, E-Test)
Back:
**Correct Sequence: C→A→D→B→E**

**C** - VNet Integration: Connect App Service to VNet subnet FIRST
**A** - Service Endpoint: Enable Microsoft.Sql service endpoint on the subnet
**D** - Firewall Rules: Update SQL Database firewall to allow subnet access
**B** - Disable Public Access: Turn off public internet access to SQL Database
**E** - Test Connectivity: Verify end-to-end secure connection works

**CRITICAL:** Must establish VNet integration and service endpoints BEFORE disabling public access to prevent connectivity loss

Front: What is the complete Container Security Pipeline implementation for Azure Container Registry that ensures only secure images reach production?
Back:
**Three-Layer Security Approach:**

**1. Microsoft Defender for Containers**
• Native Azure vulnerability scanning solution
• Automatic detection and detailed reporting
• Integrated with Azure Security Center

**2. ACR Tasks for Build Pipeline**
• Automated scanning during CI/CD process
• Implements shift-left security principles
• Catches vulnerabilities early in development

**3. Azure Policy for Enforcement**
• Deny deployment of unscanned images
• Block images with critical vulnerabilities
• Ensure only compliant images reach production

**Result:** Defender scans, ACR Tasks automates, Policy enforces = Complete security pipeline

Front: Azure Container Instances (ACI) scaling behavior vs AKS - what is the fundamental limitation and process?
Back:
**ACI Fundamental Limitation:** NO in-place auto-scaling support

**ACI Scaling Process:**
1. Delete the existing container group (az container delete)
2. Modify deployment template/command with new resource specs (CPU cores, memory GB, container count)
3. Redeploy the container group (az container create with updated parameters)

**ACI vs AKS Comparison:**
• **ACI:** Delete/redeploy with brief interruption
• **AKS:** In-place Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) with zero downtime

**Mnemonic:** ACI = 'A Container, Immutable' - To change it, you must replace it entirely

**Exam Tip:** Choose AKS for production workloads requiring auto-scaling

Front: What are Container Apps ingress configuration options and when would you use each?
Back:
**External Ingress:**
• Exposes app to internet traffic
• Provides public FQDN (e.g., app.kindcliff-123.eastus.azurecontainerapps.io)
• Use for: Public-facing APIs, web applications

**Internal Ingress:**
• VNet-only access - no internet exposure
• Private connectivity within Container Apps Environment
• Use for: Internal microservices, backend APIs

**Disabled:**
• No HTTP ingress at all
• Use for: Background jobs, queue processors

**Key Configuration Points:**
• Target Port: Must match the port your container listens on (80, 8080, 3000)
• Traffic Splitting: Enable blue/green deployments with revision weight distribution

Front: Explain the difference between Fault Domains (FD) and Update Domains (UD) in Azure and their impact on VM availability.
Back:
**Fault Domains (FD) - Hardware Isolation:**
• Represents VMs sharing common physical rack, power source, network switch
• VMs in same FD can fail together during hardware issues
• Maximum 3 fault domains in most Azure regions
• Azure automatically distributes VMs across FDs in availability sets

**Update Domains (UD) - Maintenance Isolation:**
• Represents VMs that can be updated/rebooted together during planned maintenance
• Only one UD updated at a time during planned maintenance
• Up to 20 update domains (default 5)
• Ensures portion of application remains running during updates

**Real-World Impact:**
• **Availability Sets:** Distribute VMs across both FDs and UDs automatically
• **VMSS Uniform:** Up to 5 fault domains with platform-managed spreading
• **VMSS Flexible:** Up to 1000 fault domains with maximum spreading capability

**Key Concept:** FD = Hardware failure protection, UD = Maintenance isolation

Front: Compare VMSS Orchestration Modes: Uniform vs Flexible - features, limitations, and use cases.
Back:
**Uniform Mode:**
• **Instance Identity:** Identical VMs (same size/config)
• **Max Fault Domains:** Up to 5 FDs (Platform Managed)
• **Scale-in Policy:** Automatic (newest/oldest first)
• **Load Balancer:** Required for auto-scaling
• **Autoscale Support:** Full support (horizontal)
• **Best Use Case:** Stateless apps, web tiers

**Flexible Mode:**
• **Instance Identity:** Mixed VM sizes & types allowed
• **Max Fault Domains:** Up to 1000 FDs (Max Spreading)
• **Scale-in Policy:** Manual instance selection
• **Load Balancer:** Optional (manual assignment)
• **Autoscale Support:** Limited (manual management)
• **Best Use Case:** Stateful apps, databases

**Exam Memory Aid:** Uniform = Auto-scaling web apps | Flexible = Manual control for complex workloads

Front: What is the D-G-W-C sequence for migrating encrypted VMs in Azure and why is each step critical?
Back:
**D-G-W-C Sequence: 'Don't Go Without Coffee'**

**D - Deallocate**
• Stop VM and release compute resources
• Command: az vm deallocate --resource-group SourceRG --name EncryptedVM

**G - Create Resource Group**
• Prepare destination resource group
• Command: az group create --name TargetRG --location eastus

**W - Wait for Deletion**
• CRITICAL STEP: az vm wait --deleted
• Prevents 'resource still in use' errors
• Must wait for Azure to complete deletion process

**C - reCreate VM**
• Recreate VM with encrypted disk in target RG
• Command: az vm create --attach-os-disk EncryptedOSDisk

**Why Portal Move Fails:** Azure Portal 'Move' button does NOT work for encrypted VMs
**Key Vault Access:** Target RG needs permissions to Key Vault containing ADE encryption keys

Front: What are the App Service runtime and OS constraints, and which combinations are NOT possible?
Back:
**Windows Only Runtimes:**
• ASP.NET Framework
• .NET Framework (legacy)

**Linux Only Runtimes:**
• Ruby
• Docker Multi-Container

**Cross-Platform Runtimes (Both Windows & Linux):**
• .NET Core/.NET 5+
• Node.js
• PHP
• Python
• Java

**CRITICAL EXAM TRAP:**
You CANNOT run .NET Framework (requires Windows) and Ruby (requires Linux) in the same App Service Plan because they require different OS types

**Multiple Apps Constraint:**
All apps in a plan share CPU/memory and MUST match the plan OS (all Windows OR all Linux)

**Code vs Docker Publishing:**
• Code: Native runtimes, simpler deployment
• Docker: Custom runtimes, more flexibility, multi-container only on Linux

Front: How do you deploy and configure the Network Watcher Agent, and what are its primary use cases?
Back:
**Network Watcher Agent Deployment:**

**VM Extension Names:**
• Windows: Microsoft.Azure.NetworkWatcher.NetworkWatcherAgentWindows
• Linux: Microsoft.Azure.NetworkWatcher.NetworkWatcherAgentLinux

**Deployment Methods:**
1. **Azure Portal:** VM → Extensions + Applications → Add NetworkWatcherAgent
2. **Azure CLI:** az vm extension set --name NetworkWatcherAgentLinux --publisher Microsoft.Azure.NetworkWatcher
3. **Auto-Install:** Automatically deployed when packet capture is initiated

**Packet Capture Features:**
• Traffic filtering by protocol, IPs, ports
• Maximum 18000 seconds capture duration
• Storage to VM file system or Azure Storage Account
• Analysis with Wireshark or Network Monitor (.cap files)

**Primary Use Cases:**
• Network connectivity troubleshooting
• Packet loss and performance analysis
• Security investigation of suspicious traffic
• Application traffic monitoring and bandwidth analysis

Front: What is the complete Azure Disk Encryption (ADE) end-to-end flow including all management considerations?
Back:
**6-Step ADE Implementation Flow:**

**1. Create VM**
• Deploy VM using Portal, CLI, or PowerShell

**2. Create Key Vault**
• Provision with -EnabledForDiskEncryption property
• Key Vault stores encryption keys and secrets

**3. Enable ADE via PowerShell**
• Use Set-AzVmDiskEncryptionExtension cmdlet
• Reference the Key Vault for key management

**4. Disks Encrypted**
• OS/data disks encrypted using BitLocker (Windows) or DM-Crypt (Linux)
• Keys managed securely in Key Vault

**5. Disable/Decrypt (if needed)**
• Use ARM template from Azure Quickstart Templates
• Recommended method for scale deployments

**6. Management Interaction**
• Manual (PowerShell/Portal) vs ARM template settings can override each other
• ARM template enforcement overrides manual changes on deployment

**Key Exam Point:** Understand interaction between manual and ARM-based encryption management

Front: Compare Azure VM sizes and series - when would you choose each type?
Back:
**General Purpose (D, B, Av2):**
• Balanced CPU-to-memory ratio
• Use for: Web servers, small-medium databases, dev/test environments
• B-series: Burstable performance for variable workloads

**Compute Optimized (F):**
• High CPU-to-memory ratio
• Use for: Application servers, batch processing, web servers with high traffic

**Memory Optimized (E, M):**
• High memory-to-CPU ratio
• Use for: Relational databases, in-memory analytics, SAP applications

**Storage Optimized (L):**
• High disk throughput and IOPS
• Use for: Big Data applications, NoSQL databases, data warehousing

**GPU (N):**
• Graphics processing units
• Use for: AI/ML training, graphics rendering, video processing

**High Performance Compute (H):**
• Highest performance CPUs
• Use for: Scientific computing, simulations, financial modeling

**Resizing:** Requires VM restart, check target size availability in region/zone

Front: What are the differences between Azure Backup and Azure Site Recovery, and when would you use each?
Back:
**Azure Backup:**
• **Purpose:** Data protection and recovery
• **Method:** Agentless VM backup service
• **Recovery Types:** File-level, disk-level, full VM restore
• **Storage:** Uses Recovery Services Vault
• **Scheduling:** Point-in-time recovery with retention policies
• **Use Case:** Operational backup, accidental deletion, corruption recovery

**Azure Site Recovery (ASR):**
• **Purpose:** Business continuity and disaster recovery
• **Method:** VM replication to another region or on-premises
• **Recovery Types:** Full application stack failover/failback
• **Storage:** Replicates to target location
• **Timing:** Near real-time replication
• **Use Case:** Regional disasters, planned/unplanned failovers, business continuity

**Key Difference:** Backup = Point-in-time data recovery | ASR = Continuous availability and disaster recovery

Front: Explain VM disk types and optimal caching strategies for different workloads.
Back:
**Disk Types:**
• **Standard HDD:** Dev/test environments, backup storage (high latency, low cost)
• **Standard SSD:** Better latency than HDD, web applications, light workloads
• **Premium SSD:** Production workloads, databases, high IOPS requirements
• **Ultra Disk:** Highest performance, SAP HANA, SQL Server, dynamic performance tuning

**Disk Caching Strategies:**
• **OS Disk:** Read/Write caching (default and recommended)
• **Data Disk Options:**
- None: Direct disk access, high write workloads
- ReadOnly: Best for SQL Server data files, read-heavy workloads
- ReadWrite: Balanced workloads, file servers

**Temp Disk Characteristics:**
• SSD storage on physical host
• Use for page files, swap files, tempdb
• Data lost on: VM deallocate, resize, host failure
• Not suitable for persistent data storage

**Performance Limits:** Each disk type has IOPS and throughput limits per disk and per VM

Front: Compare App Service Plan scaling methods: Scale Up vs Scale Out, and when to use each.
Back:
**Scale Up (Vertical Scaling):**
• **Action:** Change Pricing Tier/SKU (B1→S1, P1V2→P2V2)
• **Effect:** More CPU, memory, disk space, features per instance
• **Impact:** Causes application restart during change
• **Use When:** Need more processing power per instance, additional features

**Scale Out (Horizontal Scaling):**
• **Action:** Increase/decrease instance count
• **Effect:** Distribute load across more/fewer VM instances
• **Impact:** No downtime for existing instances (new ones added)
• **Methods:** Manual adjustment or automatic (autoscale rules)

**Critical Exam Concept:**
You scale the **App Service Plan**, not individual Web Apps
All apps in the plan share the scaled resources

**Autoscale Requirements:**
• Available in Standard, Premium, Isolated tiers
• Rules-based (CPU, memory, queue length, schedule)
• Instance limits: minimum, maximum, default

**Cost Impact:** Scale Up increases per-instance cost | Scale Out increases total cost through more instances

Front: What are deployment slots in App Service, their configuration options, and slot-specific settings?
Back:
**Deployment Slots Overview:**
• Live apps for staging and testing before production
• Each slot has its own hostname (e.g., myapp-staging.azurewebsites.net)
• Available in Standard, Premium, Isolated tiers only

**Slot Operations:**
1. **Deploy** new version to non-production slot
2. **Test** thoroughly in staging environment
3. **Swap** staging and production slots
4. **Rollback** by swapping again if needed

**Slot-Specific Settings:**
• **Connection Strings:** Different databases for staging vs production
• **App Settings:** Environment variables, API keys, feature flags
• **Configuration:** Mark as 'Deployment slot setting' to prevent swapping
• **Purpose:** Maintain environment isolation and prevent data exposure

**Swap Process Benefits:**
• Azure warms up staging slot instances before swap
• Zero or minimal downtime
• Automatic rollback capability
• Configuration stickiness for environment-specific settings

**Auto-Swap:** Automatically swap to production after deployment completion

Front: Describe VM Network Interface (NIC) configuration rules and IP addressing options.
Back:
**NIC Configuration Rules:**
• VM requires ≥1 NIC to connect to VNet/subnet
• **Primary NIC:** Cannot delete without deleting VM, contains default gateway
• **Secondary NICs:** Depend on VM size, used for network appliances/routing
• Can associate Public/Private IPs and NSGs with NICs

**Private IP Addressing:**
• **Dynamic (Default):** Azure assigns from subnet range automatically
• **Static (Recommended for servers):** Fixed IP within subnet range
• Assigned from VNet subnet address space

**Public IP Addressing:**
• **Purpose:** Enable inbound/outbound internet connectivity
• **SKUs:** Basic (older) or Standard (zone-redundant, secure by default)
• **Assignment:** Dynamic (Basic only) or Static (recommended)
• **DNS Label:** Optional, creates FQDN for Public IP

**Network Security Groups (NSGs):**
• Filter traffic with allow/deny rules
• Priority range: 100-4096 (lower number = higher priority)
• Can attach to NICs or subnets
• Default rules: AllowVNetInbound, DenyAllInbound, AllowInternetOutbound

Front: Compare Azure Monitor, Application Insights, and Log Analytics - when would you use each?
Back:
**Azure Monitor (Platform Level):**
• **Data Sources:** Platform metrics (CPU, memory, network, disk)
• **Scope:** Infrastructure and resource-level monitoring
• **Alerts:** Metric-based alerts and log query alerts
• **Use Case:** Infrastructure monitoring, resource health, basic alerting

**Application Insights (Application Level):**
• **Data Sources:** Application performance, requests, dependencies, exceptions
• **Scope:** Deep application performance monitoring (APM)
• **Requirements:** Code instrumentation or auto-instrumentation
• **Features:** Request tracking, dependency mapping, performance traces
• **Use Case:** Application performance optimization, user experience monitoring

**Log Analytics (Data Platform):**
• **Purpose:** Centralized log storage and analysis
• **Query Language:** KQL (Kusto Query Language)
• **Data Sources:** Multiple services via Diagnostic Settings
• **Workspace:** Shared environment for multiple data sources
• **Use Case:** Log aggregation, custom queries, compliance reporting

**Integration:** All three services work together for comprehensive observability

Front: Compare Container services: Container Apps vs ACI vs AKS vs App Service - when to use each?
Back:
**Container Apps:**
• **Best For:** Microservices, serverless containers, event-driven apps
• **Management:** Serverless (no infrastructure)
• **Scaling:** Auto-scale including scale to zero
• **Use Case:** Modern cloud-native applications

**Azure Container Instances (ACI):**
• **Best For:** Simple containers, batch jobs, CI/CD agents
• **Management:** Minimal (container groups)
• **Scaling:** Manual scaling only (delete/redeploy)
• **Use Case:** Simple workloads, temporary tasks

**Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS):**
• **Best For:** Complex orchestration, enterprise microservices
• **Management:** Full Kubernetes control and complexity
• **Scaling:** Advanced (HPA, VPA, KEDA, cluster autoscaler)
• **Use Case:** Production Kubernetes workloads, complex applications

**App Service (Containers):**
• **Best For:** Web applications, REST APIs (containerized)
• **Management:** Managed platform (PaaS)
• **Scaling:** Auto and manual scaling
• **Use Case:** Web apps with custom runtime requirements

**Decision Factors:** Complexity needs, scaling requirements, management overhead preference

Front: Explain custom domain and SSL certificate configuration in App Service.
Back:
**Custom Domain Configuration:**
• **DNS Records Required:**
- CNAME record for www subdomain (www.domain.com → app.azurewebsites.net)
- A record for apex/root domain (domain.com → App Service IP)
- awverify TXT record for domain validation

**SSL/TLS Certificate Options:**

**App Service Managed Certificates:**
• Free SSL certificates for custom domains
• Automatically managed and renewed by Azure
• Limitation: Not available for apex domains (some exceptions with aliasing)

**Upload Your Own Certificate:**
• Import PFX certificates purchased from Certificate Authority
• Import from Azure Key Vault
• Support for both SNI SSL and IP SSL bindings

**SSL Binding Types:**
• **SNI SSL:** Multiple SSL certificates on same IP (modern browsers)
• **IP SSL:** Dedicated IP for certificate (legacy support)

**Availability:** Custom domains and SSL require Basic tier or higher
**Security:** HTTPS redirection can be enforced for all traffic

Front: What are the different VM state operations and their billing implications?
Back:
**Start:**
• **Action:** Powers on the virtual machine
• **Billing:** Compute charges apply (CPU, memory billing starts)
• **State:** VM ready for RDP/SSH connections
• **IP:** Retains same private IP, public IP if static

**Stop (OS Shutdown):**
• **Action:** Operating system shutdown only
• **Billing:** Compute charges CONTINUE (still allocated to host)
• **State:** VM allocated but not running
• **IP:** Retains all IP assignments

**Stop (Deallocate):**
• **Action:** Releases CPU, memory, and host allocation
• **Billing:** Compute charges STOP (only storage charges remain)
• **State:** VM completely deallocated
• **IP:** Private IP retained, public IP may change if dynamic

**Restart:**
• **Action:** Reboot the virtual machine
• **Billing:** Brief interruption, then continues compute billing
• **State:** Clean restart of OS

**Delete:**
• **Action:** Removes VM completely
• **Default:** Also deletes OS disk and NICs (configurable)

Front: What are Azure autoscale rules, triggers, and best practices for implementation?
Back:
**Common Autoscale Triggers:**
• **CPU Percentage:** Scale out >70%, scale in <30% (most common)
• **Memory Percentage:** Available on newer VM generations (DS v3+)
• **Network In/Out:** Monitor bandwidth utilization patterns
• **Queue Metrics:** Service Bus queue length, Storage Queue depth
• **Schedule-based:** Business hours, predictable traffic patterns
• **Custom Metrics:** Application Insights counters, Log Analytics KQL queries

**Best Practices:**
• **Cool-down Period:** 5+ minutes between scale operations to avoid thrashing
• **Instance Limits:** Set appropriate minimum, maximum, and default values
• **Multiple Rules:** Combine metric-based and schedule-based rules
• **Health Monitoring:** Use health probes to ensure scaled instances are healthy

**Autoscale Requirements:**
• Available in Standard, Premium, Isolated App Service Plan tiers
• VMSS supports both uniform and flexible orchestration modes
• Load balancer integration for traffic distribution

**Scaling Patterns:** Predictable (schedule-based) vs Reactive (metric-based) vs Proactive (predictive)

Front: Compare VNet Integration vs Private Endpoints in App Service - purposes and implementation.
Back:
**VNet Integration (Outbound Connectivity):**
• **Purpose:** Enable App Service to make outbound calls to VNet resources
• **Direction:** FROM App Service TO VNet resources
• **Access:** VMs, Private Endpoint-enabled PaaS services, Key Vault, databases
• **Requirements:** Dedicated subnet delegated to Microsoft.Web/serverFarms (/28 or larger recommended)
• **Scope:** Regional - App Service must be in same region as VNet
• **Limitation:** Non-transitive across VNet peerings

**Private Endpoints (Inbound Connectivity):**
• **Purpose:** Provide private inbound access TO App Service
• **Direction:** FROM VNet TO App Service
• **Result:** App Service gets private IP within VNet
• **Benefit:** No public internet exposure for App Service
• **Security:** Traffic doesn't traverse public internet
• **Integration:** Works with VNet, on-premises via ExpressRoute/VPN

**Key Distinction:** VNet Integration = Outbound only | Private Endpoints = Inbound only

**Combined Usage:** Use both together for complete private connectivity (App Service ↔ VNet resources)

Front: Compare Infrastructure as Code options: ARM Templates vs Bicep vs Terraform.
Back:
**ARM Templates (Azure Resource Manager):**
• **Format:** Declarative JSON templates
• **Scope:** Azure-native, first-party solution
• **Features:** Idempotent deployments, resource dependencies
• **Deployment:** Portal, CLI (az deployment group create), PowerShell
• **Benefits:** Native Azure integration, comprehensive resource support
• **Drawbacks:** JSON complexity, verbose syntax

**Bicep:**
• **Format:** Domain Specific Language (DSL) with cleaner syntax
• **Relationship:** Transpiles to ARM JSON templates
• **Benefits:** Simpler syntax, modular design, type safety
• **Deployment:** Same as ARM (uses ARM APIs behind scenes)
• **Scope:** Azure-specific, Microsoft-developed
• **Migration:** Easy migration from existing ARM templates

**Terraform:**
• **Format:** HashiCorp Configuration Language (HCL)
• **Scope:** Multi-cloud (Azure, AWS, GCP, on-premises)
• **State Management:** Requires state file management
• **Benefits:** Multi-cloud consistency, mature ecosystem
• **Provider:** Uses Azure provider (azurerm)

**Key Point:** All three achieve Infrastructure as Code with different approaches and complexity levels

Front: What are Azure Storage account types, their capabilities, and appropriate use cases?
Back:
**General Purpose v2 (GPv2) - Recommended:**
• **Services:** Blobs, Files, Queues, Tables
• **Access Tiers:** Hot, Cool, Archive for cost optimization
• **Features:** All storage services, lifecycle management, versioning
• **Use Case:** Most scenarios, comprehensive storage needs

**General Purpose v1 (GPv1) - Legacy:**
• **Limitation:** Classic deployment model, limited features vs GPv2
• **Migration:** Should upgrade to GPv2 for better features
• **Use Case:** Legacy applications (migrate to GPv2 recommended)

**Premium Performance:**
• **Page Blobs:** High IOPS, low latency for VM disks
• **File Shares:** High-performance file storage
• **Block Blobs:** High-throughput scenarios
• **Use Case:** Performance-critical workloads

**FileStorage:**
• **Specialization:** Premium file shares only
• **Performance:** High IOPS and throughput for file workloads
• **Use Case:** High-performance file sharing scenarios

**Key Decision Factors:** Performance requirements, services needed, access patterns, cost optimization

Front: Provide examples of blob lifecycle management policies and their business use cases.
Back:
**Common Lifecycle Patterns:**

**Data Aging Policy:**
• Hot → Cool after 30 days of no access (cost optimization)
• Cool → Archive after 90 days in Cool tier (long-term storage)
• Delete blobs after 365 days (compliance retention)

**Log Management Policy:**
• Application logs → Cool after 7 days
• Log archives → Archive after 30 days
• Delete logs after 2555 days (7 years compliance)

**Backup Retention Policy:**
• Recent backups → Hot for 30 days (quick restore)
• Monthly backups → Cool for 12 months
• Yearly backups → Archive for 7 years
• Delete after retention period expires

**Development Lifecycle:**
• Build artifacts → Cool after 90 days
• Old build artifacts → Delete after 180 days
• Version snapshots → Archive after 365 days

**Business Benefits:**
• **Cost Optimization:** Automatic tier transitions reduce storage costs
• **Compliance:** Automated retention and deletion policies
• **Management:** Reduces manual storage administration
• **Performance:** Keeps frequently accessed data in hot tier

Front: Compare Azure Files vs Azure File Sync - use cases and implementation scenarios.
Back:
**Azure Files (Cloud-Native):**
• **Type:** Fully managed file shares in the cloud
• **Protocols:** SMB 2.1, SMB 3.0, NFS 4.1 (preview)
• **Access:** Direct cloud access from anywhere
• **Authentication:** Azure AD, on-premises AD, storage account keys
• **Use Cases:** Cloud-first applications, file sharing across cloud VMs, application data

**Azure File Sync (Hybrid Solution):**
• **Type:** Hybrid file storage bridging on-premises and cloud
• **Architecture:** On-premises Windows Server + Azure Files synchronization
• **Cloud Tiering:** Frequently accessed files local, infrequent files in cloud
• **Cache:** Local server acts as cache for cloud file share
• **Benefits:** Centralized management, distributed access, cloud backup

**When to Use Azure Files:**
• Cloud-native applications
• Simple file sharing requirements
• No on-premises infrastructure

**When to Use File Sync:**
• Hybrid environments with on-premises servers
• Need local performance with cloud scalability
• Gradual cloud migration scenarios
• Multiple office locations needing shared files
